video.title: iOS Development Course - Use Swift 5 and UIKit to Build a Netflix Clone
video.description:
Learn how to use Swift 5, UIKit, and Xcode to develop iOS apps by building a Netflix clone. You will learn how to implement the MVVM design pattern.

✏️ Course developed by Amr. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCIGbW54bABLekk_RYlwnAzg

💻 Github Repo: https://github.com/amrhossam96/Netflix-clone

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction and App Demo
⌨️ (0:02:28) Creating new Xcode Project
⌨️ (0:05:41) Creating MainTabBarViewController
⌨️ (0:16:38) Setting HomeViewController TableView
⌨️ (0:30:07) Setting home TableViewCell and it’s CollectionView
⌨️ (0:38:46) Creating Table’s HeaderView
⌨️ (0:59:35) Customizing the navigation bar
⌨️ (1:10:17) Setting Tableview sections titles
⌨️ (1:19:21) Sending URL Requests and Parsing JSON response
⌨️ (1:40:11) Using Extensions
⌨️ (1:42:24) Consuming API To Fetch Data for each Section
⌨️ (1:59:20) Refactoring Models
⌨️ (2:01:50) Creating Custom CollectionViewCell
⌨️ (2:08:24) Passing data to the CollectionView 
⌨️ (2:22:49) Viewing poster images inside CollectionViewCell
⌨️ (2:24:27) Creating Upcoming TableView inside Upcoming Tab
⌨️ (2:31:55) Creating custom TableViewCell from the upcoming table
⌨️ (2:40:00) Creating TitleViewModel
⌨️ (2:50:11) Creating Top Search TableView inside TopSearch tab
⌨️ (3:01:06) Creating SearchResultsViewController to display search results
⌨️ (3:11:21) Querying database for individual movie
⌨️ (3:20:50) Using YouTube API
⌨️ (3:28:51) Parsing YouTube API Response
⌨️ (3:35:19) Handling selections of cells (Tapping on cells)
⌨️ (3:38:37) Creating TitlePreviewViewController
⌨️ (4:06:11) Refactoring TableViewHeader Hero title
⌨️ (4:13:03) Handling Tapping across all ViewControllers
⌨️ (4:29:26) Core Data (Best Practices)
⌨️ (5:07:36) Using Notification Center to update ViewControllers

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: ꧁ Abraham ꧂
topLevelComment.text: Guys don't forget to pause the video and try these ideas yourself and then start watching again, I fell into the trap of just following along without actually learning so many times that I felt quite stupid for a long time. It's the only way of escaping tutorial hell. Not saying that freeCodeCamp is bad or anything (they are a valuable resource and I own so much to them) but just make sure that you don't watch along without absorbing what is actually being said and done. Hope you don't repeat my mistakes.

replies.author: babyhands
replies.text: @Felipe carrasco galindo Make sure your JSON fields are the exact same as the API response. So the results variable under TrendingMovieResponse need to be "results". The same applies to "id", "movie_type", etc. Those words need to match character for character, including case sensitivity. Hope this helps.

topLevelComment.author: Christiano Gontijo
topLevelComment.text: This is a good tutorial, however, you are not using the MVVM pattern in this project AT ALL. The basic principle of MVVM is to decouple the business logics and the data sources from the view controllers, which is not quite what you have in the finished project. I suggest you change the description and remove the mention to MVVM to avoid misleading beginners. MVVM is a great pattern if you use it correctly. Hope you take this comment constructively, and overall I really like your videos, thank you.

replies.author: Coder's Corner
replies.text:
@demir dereli 
1. Swift is okay.
2. But you are stuck with those old, sh*tty, improperly documented frameworks.
3. I actually wanted to do coding for Mac rather than iPhone.
4. iPhone documentation with Ray Wenderlich is a bit better.
5. The problem is that those libraries are always changing.
6. So if they have a tutorial on some topic, it will not work in 2 years.

replies.author: demir dereli
replies.text: @Coder's Corner No time learning coding is wasted since you use those techniques everywhere. I use my previous knowledge all the time when doing app dev.

replies.author: demir dereli
replies.text: @Coder's Corner Well in that case swift has excelent documentation and is really easy to start development with. I have been doing web development and hated js and the whole tech stack changing every 3 weeks. Switched over to native mobile dev. Took me about 2 months to get comfortable. I still am not there yet but swift is easy, fast and fun to learn. I am now starting to learn flutter as a back-up since building small apps natively is a waste of time since you need to port them over but give swift a try and you will start to love it. Apple has been focusing more on developers lately (since 2014) and it's nothing like the cocoa / objc times. Apple has a framework for everything and if you are using swift they are well documented. (Documentation for obj-c and cocoa sucks  I agree with you there)

replies.author: Coder's Corner
replies.text:
@demir dereli 
1. No, not really.
2. To be honest I wanted to develop apps for myself.
3. I have tried Python since and the documentation is excellent.
4. Also I have tried Powershell and C# and Microsoft's and they have amazing documentation as well.
5. I am salty because I have wasted so much time on such a bullshit that is C# & Objective C and Cocoa.

replies.author: demir dereli
replies.text: @Coder's Corner Are you salty because you couldn't get the job you wanted?
